clinical_study.official_title: Hypophosphatemia In Infants With Severe Bronchiolitis: Prevalence And Risk Factors

brief_summary.textblock: Bronchiolitis is a major public health problem and the leading cause of paediatric intensive care unit admission in infants. Hypophosphatemia is common in adult intensive care units and was associated with an increase of the duration of mechanical ventilation and the length of stay. Our hypothesis is that hypophosphatemia is common in bronchiolitis and could be a marker of severity.

primary_outcome.measure: hypophosphatemia occurrence in severe bronchiolitis in infants admitted in a pediatric intensive care unit
primary_outcome.time_frame: At any time in the first 5th days after Pediatric intensive care admission
primary_outcome.description: A serum phosphorus level< 1.55mmol/L defines the hypophosphatemia.

arm_group.description: Infant less than 3 months with severe bronchiolitis admitted in a pediatric intensive care unit, with hypophosphatemia in the first 5th days
Infant less than 3 months with severe bronchiolitis admitted in a pediatric intensive care unit, without hypophosphatemia

intervention.intervention_name: hypophosphatemia occurrence in infants with severe bronchiolitis admitted in a pediatric intensive care unit
intervention.description: Serum phosphorus level < 1.55 mmol/L at any time between admission and the 5th day.

study_pop.textblock: Infant less than 3 months with severe bronchiolitis admitted in a pediatric intensive care unit

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age > 7 days and < 3 months of life
- Admission to the pediatric intensive care unit from 01/11/2016 to 31/03/2020
- With a diagnosis of moderate to severe bronchiolitis according to HAS 2019 criteria
Exclusion Criteria:
- Renal Failure and tubulopathy
- Previous disorder of phospho-calcium balance
- Malignant pathology
- Lenght of stay less than 24 hours
- History of cardiac, aortic or hepatic surgery
